newsitem.title: USA: Stocks extend losing streak to third day on Greenspan effect.
newsitem.headline: Stocks extend losing streak to third day on Greenspan effect.

text.p: Stocks ended lower for the third day in a row Friday as the market remained under a cloud following Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's comments about high stock prices and hints about an interest rate hike.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 47.33 points at 6,877.74. For the week, the index lost 53.88 points.
In the broader market, declining issues beat advances 1,454 to 1,027 on active volume of 508 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Many technology stocks were under selling pressure, but shares in some key leaders in the sector managed to rally.
But by and large, analysts said the market remained under a pall that was unlikely to lift before Greenspan's second round of testimony next Wednesday to the House of Representatives.

"We'll have to see what happens after everybody absorbs his next comments," said Edgar Peters, chief investment strategist at PanAgora Asset Management Inc. "I think we'll have a lot of sideways volatility for the time being."

For now, analysts said, the wind is clearly out of the stock market's sails, which leaves the sentiment-sensitive sectors like technology that bounded higher in January on heavy fund inflows and high optimism, particularly vulnerable.

On Wednesday, Greenspan rattled the stock market as he spoke in surprisingly blunt terms of his concerns in his semi-annual report on the economy to the Senate, about the risks of inflation as well as the dramatic increase in stock prices.
"I think there's still more to work out for the techs," said Grace Messner, vice president of equity management at Wilmington Trust. "A lot of the stocks are still extremely expensive."

Networking stocks met with another session of stiff selling, as investors reassess the former high-flying group. Ascend Communications Inc. fell 4-3/4 to 52-1/4 and Bay Networks Inc. shed 1/4 to 19-1/8.
Industry leader Cisco Systems Inc. closed up 9/16 to 55-5/8, however, one of several blue-chip tech stocks to show signs of recovery.

Among the weakest Dow components was drug giant Merck & Co., which lost 1-3/4 to 92-1/8. Other decliners among pharmaceutical stocks included Pfizer Inc., down 3/4 to 91-5/8 and American Home Products Corp., down 5/8 to 64.
J.P. Morgan & Co. Inc. fell 2-1/8 to 105, and Citicorp fell 2-5/8 to 116-3/4.

Fleet Financial Group Inc. bucked the trend, however, rising 1-1/2 to 61 on speculation about a possible merger with NationsBank Corp. Late in the day, Fleet said it knew of "no corporate developments" to account for its stock's activity. NationsBank, which fell 1-1/4 to 60, declined comment.
In individual issues, Cigna Corp. rose 1/4 to 152-7/8 after announcing an agreement to acquire Healthsource Inc. for $21.75 a share. Healthsource gained four to 20-7/8.
General Cigar Holdings Inc. jumped five to 23 in the cigar maker's debut on the NYSE following its six million share initial public offering.
Ford Motor Co. said it would sell up to 20 percent of its Hertz car rental unit through an initial public offering. Shares in Ford closed unchanged at 32-7/8.
Intuit Inc. fell 2-3/4 to 22-5/8 after the financial software company said it expects slowing sales for at least the next two quarters.
The Nasdaq Composite index fell 3.66 points to 1,309.00.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks lost 4.25 points at 790.82. The American Stock Exchange index slipped 0.93 to 594.24.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 2.38 to 415.51. The average share was down 25 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 7,559.418 down 43.173 or 0.57 percent.
